caption: The system is broken down into 3 mechanisms.
The first mechanism is the Plasma Generation.
Given two conducting plates and a battery,
if we connect them,
we get an electric field between the plates.
We can increase the field with higher voltage or a sharper cathode and duller anode.
If the electric field is strong enough, nearby air molecules (Nitrogen),
will ionize, resulting in an electron, a positive ion, and a photon.
The electron and positive ion are accelerated towards the plates by the field.
The electron will collide with other air molecules,
causing more air molecules to ionize in a phenomenon called electron cascading.
This creates a plasma region around the cathode, known as a corona discharge.
The minimum voltage for this to occur is governed by Peek's Law.
The maximum voltage is the arcing voltage, given by Paschen's Law.
Summarizing...
The second mechanism is Ion Acceleration.
Consider the positive ion created from the first mechanism.
The electric field generates an electrostatic force on the ion.
If we consider the electrostatic force on all N ions,
this is equal to the thrust generated by the system.
We can then derive the thrust-to-power efficiency, θ.
Summarizing...
The third mechanism is Momentum Transfer — a different view of how thrust is generated.
By Newton's second law, the ion will accelerate and gain some velocity.
The ion will collide with neutral air molecules,
after travelling some mean free path, λ.
The total momentum transfer is momentum lost + momentum gained.
Force is equal to the rate of change of momentum,
so summing over all ions gives the thrust force — same equation as before.
Summarizing...
Recapping...
Now, we can discuss two AC considerations.
1. Pulsing the DC voltage to increase ion generation while minimizing losses in efficiency.
2. Using a linear accelerator to boost the ions, given the same voltage
This may look like adding accelerating rings between the electrodes.
